concept.title: Index elements
concept.shortdesc: The content of the indexterm elements provides the text for the entries in a generated index. indexterm elements can be nested to create secondary and tertiary index entries.

conbody.p: The following elements contain information that processors use to generate indexes.

dlentry.dd: Instructs a processor to generate an index entry. The start and end attributes on the indexterm element can specify index ranges. If an indexterm element does not contain an index-see or index-see-also element, a locator is generated.
Instructs a processor to generate a see reference. See references direct a reader to the preferred term.
Instructs a processor to generate a see also reference. See also references direct a reader to an alternate index entry for additional information.

draft-comment.author: Kristen J Eberlein
draft-comment.p: Can we remove the word "typically" from the above statements?
27 July 2019: I'm adding additional information here, to clarify the issues:

ul.li: Not all DITA processors support indexing
Indexing is often relevant only to print-based delivery formats.
AFAIK, page references are ONLY relevant to print-based delivery formats.

draft-comment.p: I think my preference would be to have a statement clarifying the above matters at the start of this content, and then avoid wiggle words such as "typically."

draft-comment.author: Eliot Kimber
draft-comment.p: The statements have to be qualified since the standard can't require index entries to use page numbers. "normally" might be better than typically.
In the municipal code work I've been doing, the indexes point to section and paragraph numbers, not to page numbers.

conbody.p: How the index elements are combined, the location of indexterm elements, and the hierarchy of the DITA maps all effect how the index elements are processed and the resulting generated index entries.
